articles.headline: Netanyahu Tactics Anger Many U.S. Jews, Deepening a Divide
articles.snippet: Even many supporters said they were appalled at the Israeli prime minister’s warning about Arab voters and his renunciation of a two-state solution.
articles.abstract: Even many supporters said they were appalled at the Israeli prime minister’s warning about Arab voters and his renunciation of a two-state solution.
articles.lead_paragraph: Long before the latest election in Israel, Benjamin Netanyahu was a polarizing figure among American Jews. But even many of his supporters said this week that they were appalled at his last-minute bid to mobilize Jewish voters by warning that Arabs were going to the polls in droves, and his renunciation of a two-state solution to the Palestinian crisis.

articles.headline: Richard Fisher, Often Wrong but Seldom Boring, Leaves the Fed
articles.snippet: The departure of Mr. Fisher, who stepped down on Thursday, means that the Fed is losing the most outspoken internal opponent of its stimulus campaign.
articles.abstract: The departure of Mr. Fisher, who stepped down on Thursday, means that the Fed is losing the most outspoken internal opponent of its stimulus campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS — In a decade as president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, Richard W. Fisher was frequently mistaken in his economic predictions but seldom boring.

articles.headline: Guardian Names Katharine Viner as Editor
articles.snippet: Ms. Viner succeeds Alan Rusbridger, who oversaw the paper for 20 years.
articles.abstract: Ms. Viner succeeds Alan Rusbridger, who oversaw the paper for 20 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Guardian appointed its first female editor on Friday, giving Katharine Viner, the current editor in chief of The Guardian’s United States operation, the job of leading the liberal British newspaper and media group as it seeks to expand its global ambitions.
articles.byline: By Ravi Somaiya and Stephen Castle

articles.headline: A Scary Movie: Filling Your 401(k) With Company Stock
articles.snippet: Employer stock in 401(k) plans is less common than it used to be, but it’s still in plenty of them, including the plan at RadioShack, which filed for bankruptcy protection last month.
articles.abstract: Employer stock in 401(k) plans is less common than it used to be, but it’s still in plenty of them, including the plan at RadioShack, which filed for bankruptcy protection last month.
articles.lead_paragraph: We’ve seen the movie before, when employees of Enron and Lehman Brothers lost large sums of money in their 401(k) plans because of investments in company stock. And now, coming to a theater (and, inevitably, a courtroom) near you, is a sequel, surely not the last, this time featuring RadioShack.

articles.headline: White House Antagonism Toward Netanyahu Grows
articles.snippet: Despite Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s election victory, he is still out of the good graces of the Obama administration, which has had to reassess its policy toward Israel.
articles.abstract: Despite Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s election victory, he is still out of the good graces of the Obama administration, which has had to reassess its policy toward Israel.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House is stepping up its antagonism toward Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu despite his victory in this week’s elections, signaling that it is in no rush to repair a historic rift between the United States and Israel.

articles.headline: Online ‘Swatting’ Becomes a Hazard for Popular Video Gamers and Police Responders
articles.snippet: Pranksters are targeting Internet gamers, calling police departments to prompt a raid that they can watch in real time as it interrupts the game’s live webcast.
articles.abstract: Pranksters are targeting Internet gamers, calling police departments to prompt a raid that they can watch in real time as it interrupts the game’s live webcast.
articles.lead_paragraph: Practical jokers have delighted for years at tormenting celebrities at home by calling in bogus reports of violence and provoking huge police responses.

articles.headline: For 2016 Run, Scott Walker Washes ‘Wiscahnsin’ Out of His Mouth
articles.snippet: The governor of Wisconsin has filtered out his regional accent, cut down rambling in speeches and started dressing to please on visits to states like New Hampshire.
articles.abstract: The governor of Wisconsin has filtered out his regional accent, cut down rambling in speeches and started dressing to please on visits to states like New Hampshire.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Out on the presidential campaign trail, Gov. Scott Walker has left “Wiscahnsin” back home in Wisconsin. He now wants to strengthen the economy, not the “ecahnahmy.” And while he once had the “ahnor” of meeting fellow Republicans, he told one group here this week that he simply enjoyed “talkin’ with y’all.”

articles.headline: Philadelphia Commissioner Steps Into Fray Between Police and Public
articles.snippet: Even in a city with a black chief of police, relations between law enforcement and the public are strained.
articles.abstract: Even in a city with a black chief of police, relations between law enforcement and the public are strained.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — When Police Commissioner Charles H. Ramsey and District Attorney R. Seth Williams appeared at a town hall meeting here on Thursday, they were prepared to explain why criminal charges had not been filed against an officer who in December fatally shot a young black man in the back of the head.

articles.headline: A Luxury Liner Docks, and the Countdown’s On
articles.snippet: The profitability of today’s giant cruise ships depends on a tightly choreographed routine that’s part Nascar pit stop, part Noah’s Ark.
articles.abstract: The profitability of today’s giant cruise ships depends on a tightly choreographed routine that’s part Nascar pit stop, part Noah’s Ark.
articles.lead_paragraph: Once a week, after touring the Caribbean, the cruise ship Oasis of the Seas calls into its home port in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., for what is called “turnaround day.”

articles.headline: From Minneapolis to ISIS: An American’s Path to Jihad
articles.snippet: The chilling progression of a Minnesota man suggests that the Islamic State may rely on recruiters inside the United States and shows how hard it is to predict who will be swept away by ideological fervor.
articles.abstract: The chilling progression of a Minnesota man suggests that the Islamic State may rely on recruiters inside the United States and shows how hard it is to predict who will be swept away by ideological fervor.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Reading back over Abdi Nur’s Twitter feed, his chilling progression from the basketball courts of South Minneapolis to the battlefields of Syria is clear.

articles.headline: Ways to Put the Boss’s Skin in the Game
articles.snippet: Two new proposals aim to make top executives think twice before taking outsize risks, because breaking rules would cost them money.
articles.abstract: Two new proposals aim to make top executives think twice before taking outsize risks, because breaking rules would cost them money.
articles.lead_paragraph: Life is not fair, I know, but this is getting ridiculous.

articles.headline: Unstated Factor in Iran Talks: Threat of Nuclear Tampering
articles.snippet: A number of officials make the case that, if a deal is reached, surveillance of Iran will intensify and covert action may become more important to ensure that Iran does not import critical materials or pursue a covert path to a bomb.
articles.abstract: A number of officials make the case that, if a deal is reached, surveillance of Iran will intensify and covert action may become more important to ensure that Iran does not import critical materials or pursue a covert path to a bomb.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In late 2012, just as President Obama and his aides began secretly sketching out a diplomatic opening to Iran, American intelligence agencies were busy with a parallel initiative: The latest spy-vs.-spy move in the decade-long effort to sabotage Tehran’s nuclear infrastructure.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and William J. Broad

articles.headline: Chicago Mayor’s Race Is Cast as a Test of Liberalism
articles.snippet: Mayor Rahm Emanuel, a former chief of staff to President Obama, faces a surprisingly competitive runoff against Jesus G. Garcia, who is supported by progressives frustrated with business-backed politics.
articles.abstract: Mayor Rahm Emanuel, a former chief of staff to President Obama, faces a surprisingly competitive runoff against Jesus G. Garcia, who is supported by progressives frustrated with business-backed politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Mayor Rahm Emanuel had just finished the quintessential municipal politics photo op, briefly inspecting a dusty street-paving project on a block of the South Side lined with tidy brick bungalows.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Julie Bosman

articles.headline: Jeb Bush’s Team Plots Vast Effort to Win Florida
articles.snippet: As former Gov. Jeb Bush moves toward a presidential run, a plan is in place to neutralize the threats that could make him more vulnerable in a state that has vexed Republicans in national elections.
articles.abstract: As former Gov. Jeb Bush moves toward a presidential run, a plan is in place to neutralize the threats that could make him more vulnerable in a state that has vexed Republicans in national elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — The political apparatus surrounding former Gov. Jeb Bush, determined to avoid embarrassment in a state that has vexed his party and family in national elections, is plotting a vast operation aimed at turning Florida into a bulwark for his presidential campaign, according to dozens of interviews.

articles.headline: Lee Kuan Yew, Founding Father and First Premier of Singapore, Dies at 91
articles.snippet: As prime minister for 31 years, Mr. Lee transformed the tiny island outpost into a modern, affluent city-state admired for its efficiency and low level of corruption.
articles.abstract: As prime minister for 31 years, Mr. Lee transformed the tiny island outpost into a modern, affluent city-state admired for its efficiency and low level of corruption.
articles.lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE — Lee Kuan Yew, who transformed the tiny outpost of Singapore into one of Asia’s wealthiest and least corrupt countries as its founding father and first prime minister, died here on Monday. He was 91.

articles.headline: Apple Opens Up to Praise New Book on Steve Jobs, and Criticize an Old One
articles.snippet: Apple brass, including its chief, Timothy D. Cook, are throwing their weight behind the unauthorized biography of Mr. Jobs, which goes on sale Tuesday.
articles.abstract: Apple brass, including its chief, Timothy D. Cook, are throwing their weight behind the unauthorized biography of Mr. Jobs, which goes on sale Tuesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Steve Jobs prized secrecy from his executives and employees during his tenure at Apple. Now his top lieutenants are speaking out — to help shape the legacy of Steve Jobs.
articles.byline: By Brian X. Chen and Alexandra Alter

articles.headline: Saudi Justice, Harsh but Able to Spare the Sword
articles.snippet: A confessed murderer’s life was spared because of little-known checks in a judicial system regularly condemned by human rights groups.
articles.abstract: A confessed murderer’s life was spared because of little-known checks in a judicial system regularly condemned by human rights groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: BURAIDA, Saudi Arabia — The murder that almost cost Bandar al-Yehiya his head started with an old debt to a close friend.

articles.headline: Americans’ Retirement Funds Increasingly Contain Tech Start-Up Stocks
articles.snippet: Drawn by fast-growing private tech companies, big money managers are purchasing their shares, betting that they’ll go public. But that outcome is hardly guaranteed.
articles.abstract: Drawn by fast-growing private tech companies, big money managers are purchasing their shares, betting that they’ll go public. But that outcome is hardly guaranteed.
articles.lead_paragraph: The retirement accounts of millions of Americans have long contained shares of stalwart companies like General Electric, Ford and Coca-Cola. Today, they are likely to include riskier private stocks from Silicon Valley start-ups like Uber, Airbnb and Pinterest.
articles.byline: By David Gelles and Conor Dougherty

articles.headline: For Clintons, a Hedge Fund in the Family
articles.snippet: When Chelsea Clinton’s husband, Marc Mezvinsky, co-founded an investment firm, Clinton family friends took an interest, illustrating how politics, family and finance can intersect.
articles.abstract: When Chelsea Clinton’s husband, Marc Mezvinsky, co-founded an investment firm, Clinton family friends took an interest, illustrating how politics, family and finance can intersect.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since marrying Chelsea Clinton five years ago, Marc Mezvinsky, a money manager, appears to have settled into his life as Bill and Hillary Clinton’s son-in-law. He has regularly appeared at charitable events, once introducing the former president at the Clinton Foundation’s celebrity poker tournament by dryly saying, “You may have heard of my father-in-law.” And at the recent N.B.A. All-Star Game, Mr. Mezvinsky took a seat next to Mr. Clinton and his partner in charitable endeavors, Dikembe Mutombo, the former basketball star.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and Steve Eder

articles.headline: At the Box Office, It’s No Longer a Man’s World
articles.snippet: Women are driving movie ticket sales to a degree rarely seen before, while young men, long the most coveted audience, are relatively AWOL.
articles.abstract: Women are driving movie ticket sales to a degree rarely seen before, while young men, long the most coveted audience, are relatively AWOL.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Heading into the all-important summer moviegoing season, two converging box-office trends are startling studios: Women are driving ticket sales to a degree rarely, if ever, seen before, while young men — long Hollywood’s most coveted audience — are relatively AWOL.

articles.headline: Two Maxims at Odds: Tell a Story, Tell the Truth
articles.snippet: The possible murder confession in HBO’s “The Jinx” has raised questions in the documentary world about the tension between accuracy and a good story.
articles.abstract: The possible murder confession in HBO’s “The Jinx” has raised questions in the documentary world about the tension between accuracy and a good story.
articles.lead_paragraph: The last interview was over. The set, a room inside a New York hotel, had gone dark. The subject, Robert A. Durst, headed for the bathroom, apparently unaware his microphone was still on. “There it is. You’re caught,” he is heard saying. “What the hell did I do? Killed them all, of course.”

articles.headline: Out of Yemen, U.S. Is Hobbled in Terror Fight
articles.snippet: The evacuation of Special Operations advisers from Yemen is the latest blow to the Obama administration’s counterterrorism campaign, which is already struggling with significant setbacks in the region, officials said.
articles.abstract: The evacuation of Special Operations advisers from Yemen is the latest blow to the Obama administration’s counterterrorism campaign, which is already struggling with significant setbacks in the region, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The evacuation of 125 United States Special Operations advisers from Yemen in the past two days is the latest blow to the Obama administration’s counterterrorism campaign, which is already struggling with significant setbacks in Syria, Libya and elsewhere in the volatile region, American officials said Sunday.

articles.headline: In Clinton Emails on Benghazi, a Rare Glimpse at Her Concerns
articles.snippet: Roughly 300 emails from Hillary Rodham Clinton’s private account were turned over to a House committee investigating the attack on the U.S. diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya, in 2012.
articles.abstract: Roughly 300 emails from Hillary Rodham Clinton’s private account were turned over to a House committee investigating the attack on the U.S. diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya, in 2012.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was a grueling hearing. A month after the September 2012 attack on the United States diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya, House Republicans grilled a top State Department official about security lapses at the outpost.
